persona.name: Harper Noelle Santiago

occupation.title: Art Director / Freelance Graphic Designer
occupation.organization: Freelance. Part-time Art Director at a small Brooklyn production studio and regular freelance clients in children's media and boutique brands.
occupation.description: Harper works primarily in visual communications: art direction for short digital campaigns, designing packaging for small organic food producers, and illustrating occasional children's-book projects. She balances client work with self-initiated print runs sold online and at weekend markets. Responsibilities include concept development, sketching, final art production in Adobe Creative Suite, liaising with printers, basic UX wireframes for small web projects, and coordinating with freelance copywriters and photographers. She manages her own schedule, negotiates contracts, invoices clients, and keeps a simple bookkeeping system. Her role requires strong visual judgment, client communication, time management under irregular hours, and the ability to explain design choices to non-designers. She also mentors a junior illustrator a few hours a month and teaches occasional evening community workshops on basic illustration for parents and kids.
skills_and_tools: Prototyping with Figma for small web projects
Layout and prepping files for print (InDesign basics)
Basic color correction and photo editing
Light social media content production (Instagram Reels, short videos)

persona.education: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Graphic Design, Pratt Institute. Took additional continuing-education courses in UX design, children's book illustration, and social media marketing. Completed a college internship at a small independent magazine and a semester-long exchange focusing on printmaking.
long_term_goals: Provide a stable, stimulating childhood and education for her children, including saving for college and travel experiences.
Grow a small, sustainable creative business (prints, occasional commissioned work, and licensed illustrations for children's media) that allows flexible hours to parent.
Own a modest, light-filled two-bedroom apartment in an accessible neighborhood where kids can play outside safely — transition from renting to owning within the next 8–10 years.
Continue developing as an artist: illustrate a children's picture book and have a solo show in a local gallery.
Be an active community member: help create neighborhood arts programming for families and advocate for better public playgrounds and safer streets.
Maintain a healthy partnership with her spouse that balances emotional labor and childcare, keeping daily life joyful despite inevitable stressors.
persona.style: Witty, warm, visually expressive. Speaks with a soft, urban New York cadence with occasional Spanglish phrases when relaxed around family or close friends. Tends toward conversational, descriptive language—uses visual metaphors ('that palette looks like late-summer peach jam') and gestures with her hands when explaining visual ideas. In professional settings she can switch to measured, clear language and templates to manage client expectations. In parenting contexts she uses an affectionate, sing-song voice for toddlers, but can be brisk and directive when deadlines or safety matter. Mannerisms include smoothing her hair back when thinking, tapping a pattern with a pen when designing, and instinctively photographing children’s drawings to archive them. She favors comfortable, creative clothing (well-worn denim, patterned blouses, and colorful sneakers), small hoop earrings, and often has paint faintly on her wrist. Online, she writes in short paragraphs with emojis and occasional memes; she values authenticity over overly polished messaging. In group settings she is approachable and laughs easily, though she sometimes withdraws after long conversations to recharge. She is bilingual conversationally in Spanish and often code-switches with relatives and long-term friends.

traits: Curious about new places, foods, and local culture; loves exploratory weekends.
Creative and visually oriented; thinks in compositions, color, and story.
Resourceful: can make thoughtful things on a tight budget.
Empathetic: notices others' moods and tries to help, especially friends and children.
Organized in bursts: uses lists, calendars, and visual boards but can be chaotic when overwhelmed.
Protective and attentive as a parent; can become anxious about safety decisions.
Sociable with other parents and creative types; enjoys coffee dates and museum mornings.
Pragmatic about finances but occasionally splurges on art supplies or a special family outing.
Resilient: bounces back after setbacks but carries quiet worries about long-term stability.
Slightly perfectionistic about her creative output; will iterate a design many times to get the 'right' look.
Playful and imaginative with children—turns mundane chores into games.
Cares about social justice and climate, and lets those convictions influence life choices.
personality.nuanced_description: Harper is a high-openness creative who seeks novelty and meaning through art and family experiences. She is reasonably conscientious—she meets deadlines and pays bills on time but is not rigid; she tolerates flexible schedules typical of freelancer life. Moderately extraverted, she enjoys social gatherings, particularly those centered on children or art, but needs solo time to recharge. Agreeable and cooperative, she often mediates group decisions among friends and in co-parenting situations, yet she keeps firm boundaries when necessary. Her neuroticism is moderate: she experiences worry—especially about finances, child safety, and future planning—but uses routines, lists, and therapy to manage anxiety. Overall she is warm, curious, and driven to combine creative work with attentive parenting.

interests: Children's literature and picture book illustration
Visiting small, independent art galleries and artist studios
Family-friendly, low-key travel to nature-oriented destinations
Local food markets and farmer's markets
Design and color theory books
Podcast listening (parenting, creativity, local politics)
Independent coffee shops that allow laptop work
Community arts programming and kid-friendly workshops
Sustainable, small-batch brands in clothing and homewares
Weekend flea markets and vintage textile hunting
Documentary-style travel films and short art documentaries
Curating playlists for different moods (work, bedtime, play)
Simple home cooking with seasonal produce
Walking neighborhood architecture and murals
Teaching kids simple art projects (collage, finger painting, cardboard construction)
Ethical parenting communities and peer support groups
Museum memberships (children’s museum + modern art museum)
Local playground 'hangouts' where families meet informally
Reading design blogs and following other illustrators on Instagram
Hosting small dinners with other families, swapping desserts and kid-swaps
likes: Morning walks with a stroller along tree-lined streets
Iced oat milk latte from a trusted local cafe
Bright, saturated colors and hand-drawn type
Children's books with diverse characters and gentle messages
Reusable snack bags and aesthetically pleasing storage jars
Simple, nourishing family meals: roasted vegetables, warm grains, rotisserie chicken
Listening to folky indie music and Latin-American singer-songwriters
Watching her toddler discover small things (bugs, puddles) and narrating it for them
A tidy, sunlight-filled corner for her sketching and laptop work
Weekend farmers’ market mornings with fresh pastries
Swap meet weekends where kids trade toys they've outgrown
Community library story hours
Using color-coded calendars for family schedules
Small rituals: Friday pizza night, bedtime story ritual with a special lamp
Secondhand clothing for kids sourced from peers and local consignment
Minimalist yet tactile children's toys (wooden blocks, cloth dolls, cardboard)
A low-key, reliable babysitter who doubles as a family friend
Seasonal rituals: apple picking in fall, sledding in winter (when kids are older)
City parks with toddler-safe splashpads in summer
A cozy corner couch nap with a warm blanket
dislikes: Overly loud, chaotic family attractions with long lines (big amusement parks)
Aggressive parenting shaming or unsolicited advice in public
Overly-sanitized plastic toys and cheap fast-fashion kids' clothes
Big-box chain restaurants that have no child-friendly accommodations
Design trends that value form over basic function for children
Clients who expect unlimited revisions for fixed-fee freelance jobs
Traffic-clogged commutes and long car trips with toddlers unless well-planned
Poorly ventilated indoor spaces and stale air in winter venues
Grandstanding political rhetoric without practical solutions
News cycles that focus on outrage rather than community problem-solving
coffee_and_cafe_preferences: Iced oat latte with a single shot of espresso on hot mornings
Support independent cafes over national chains; has a favorite on her block
Prefers cafes with a small kid-friendly corner or outdoor seating
Brings a laminated list of children’s snacks to the cafe
Uses cafes as a flexible workspace one morning a week
Likes ambient, slightly lo-fi music playlists in cafes; dislikes heavy house music
Values reliable Wi-Fi for occasional client calls
Prefers baristas who know her order to speed up pickup
Buys beans from local roasters and brews a pour-over at home on slow weekends
Keeps a small travel mug with a cork coaster to avoid spills
vacation_preferences_and_children: Prefers 5–10 day vacations that balance downtime and low-key activities; avoids cramming many attractions into one trip
Chooses destinations within a 4–6 hour travel window for toddlers (train or short flights preferred)
Seeks rentals with a kitchen, separate sleeping areas, and a safe outdoor space for children
Prioritizes kid-friendly activities: gentle nature hikes, shallow beaches with lifeguards, small local farms, puppet theaters, aquarium visits on chill days
Brings a lightweight travel stroller, portable white noise machine, favorite small blanket and two comfort toys per child
Schedules mid-day naps into the itinerary; plans adult time around overlapping nap windows
Looks for accommodations with baby gear available (pack-and-play, high chair) to avoid excess baggage
Likes to combine visiting family or friends with short trips to keep travel affordable
Prefers off-season travel to avoid crowds and overstimulation for kids
Chooses vacation rentals near local grocery shops and a reliable pharmacy
Enjoys small cultural experiences with children: local story hours, family-friendly craft classes, farmers’ markets
Brings a foldable travel art kit for children: crayons, sticker sheets, a small sketchbook
Always carries an extra outfit for each child, wet wipes, band-aids, electrolyte solution and a small first-aid pack
When possible, coordinates with other families to split babysitting duties one evening for a quiet dinner
On vacations she retains a little personal work time early in the morning for client emails and social media posts
Values experiences that create simple family rituals (morning beach walks, bakery runs) kids can anticipate
Avoids heavily scheduled 'kid camp' style excursions and instead favors free playtime in safe outdoor spaces
Enjoys places with easy public transit access rather than requiring a car seat setup
Will pay a modest premium for an apartment with a washer/dryer to avoid hand-washing children's clothes
Keeps a small roll-up changing mat and tiny portable laundry kit for quick cleanups on the road
media_and_entertainment: Follows a curated list of illustrators on Instagram for inspiration
Listens to parenting podcasts about gentle discipline and toddler sleep routines
Enjoys short design and documentary YouTube channels in the evening
Reads selected sections of design blogs and children's lit reviews between naps
Buys picture books recommended by local librarians and illustrators
Shares small behind-the-scenes posts on Instagram about her print runs, often photographed with kids nearby
Occasionally posts time-lapse videos of an illustration coming together
Watches family-friendly films on streaming services and reserves animated films for special evenings
Appreciates long-form magazine essays about urban life, art, and climate townshedding
shopping_and_brand_preferences: Prefers secondhand or small-batch children’s clothing brands for quality and sustainability
Buys home goods from independent designers or local craft fairs
Orders art supplies from specialty local shops when possible
Uses an online parent marketplace app to buy and sell used baby gear
Prefers small, transparent brands over opaque corporations; reads ingredient and materials labels
Occasional splurge: a limited-edition print or an artisan-made toy

beliefs: Climate change is an urgent, real problem that should shape family and civic choices.
Public transit improvement is essential for urban livability and children's future.
Vaccinations are important and she follows pediatrician guidance for her children.
Affordable, high-quality childcare is a policy priority that helps families and gender equality.
Arts and creative education for children matter for cognitive and emotional development.
Diversity in children's media helps all kids develop empathy and realistic role models.
Renters' rights and protections are important in expensive cities.
Small, local businesses are worth supporting when they operate ethically.
Paid parental leave should be more widely available; it helps bonding and reduces postpartum stress.
Urban parks and safe play spaces are essential public goods for children and families.
Parents should share emotional labor and household responsibilities as equally as possible.
Work-life balance is challenging but worth striving for; remote work flexibility matters.
Food access and knowing where food comes from increases healthy habits in kids.
Mental health care should be accessible and normalized for parents.
Climate-conscious consumer choices (reusable items, reduced single-use plastics) matter even at household scale.
Community networks (other parents, neighbors) are critical for resilience and social support.
Political engagement matters: voting local and participating in community meetings influences everyday life.
Media should be fact-checked; social media algorithms can distort priorities and emotions.
Design should prioritize accessibility and children's safety over aesthetic novelty.
Creative entrepreneurship is viable but requires reliable childcare and realistic financial planning.
Public libraries are invaluable community resources and one of the best places to expose kids to stories.
Over-scheduling children with many structured activities is less valuable than open-ended play.
Empathy-driven discipline (clear limits, calm consequences) is a better long-term approach than harsh punishment.
Paid community arts programs for kids and sliding-scale fees increase equity.
There is systemic inequality in education access that needs policy remedies.
Trash reduction and composting at home are practical ways families can contribute to environmental health.
Healthcare (including perinatal mental health services) should be prioritized for new parents.
She believes in teaching her children basic Spanish and English fluency to preserve cultural heritage and cognitive benefits.
School playground safety and traffic calming near schools should be non-negotiable city priorities.
She trusts science-informed parenting guidance but adapts it to fit her family’s values.
She believes in saving for her children's future (education, emergencies) while still enjoying life now—finding a balance.
She thinks it's important to model activism and civic engagement for her kids, even through small actions like neighborhood cleanups.
She believes that art can be a tool for social change and personal resilience.
She thinks gender roles should be flexible and children should be free to express themselves.
skills: Professional-level mastery of Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop for both digital and print work.
Hand-illustration skills: watercolor washes, line work, and simple narrative layouts for picture books.
Project management for small creative teams and freelance client coordination.
Basic web design and UX wireframing with Figma.
Photography composition for product shots and social media.
Social media content creation: short-form video, caption writing, basic analytics tracking.
Simple bookkeeping and invoicing for freelancing: setting rates, tracking expenses, issuing invoices.
Childcare practical skills: soothing techniques, nap scheduling, baby-first-aid basics.
Budgeting and household finance management for a middle-income family.
Teaching basic art techniques to toddlers and small groups of children.
Spanish conversational fluency for family communication and simple translation tasks.
Negotiation skills for client rates and freelance contracts.
Time-blocking and calendar coordination to juggle client deadlines and family routines.
Basic home maintenance knowledge: changing light fixtures, patching drywall, installing curtain rods.
Culinary skills for family meals: roasting vegetables, quick soups, baking simple breads and muffins.

general: Multitasks frequently: answers client emails with one hand and soothes a toddler with the other.
Photographs children's art and milestones obsessively and stores them digitally in dated folders.
Keeps a visible family calendar with color-coded entries for work, daycare, and spouse commitments.
Uses lists and sticky notes for grocery, project steps, and packing checklists.
Checks social media in short bursts throughout the day, particularly Instagram and parenting groups.
Is quick to volunteer to organize a potluck or playdate among neighbors.
Carries a small kit in her diaper bag: snacks, wipes, bandaids, a mini art kit, and a spare shirt.
Sings improvised songs to calm kids during public meltdowns.
Tends to apologize quickly when small conflicts happen with other parents, then advocates calmly for what her children need.
Keeps a low-key evening wind-down routine: dishes, lay out clothes for next day, 20–30 minutes of personal reading or design work after kids are asleep.

morning: Wakes around 6:15–6:45 AM depending on children's wake times.
Makes coffee and gets a 20–30 minute block of work done (emails, small edits) before kids fully wake if spouse can take first wake.
Prepares a simple breakfast: oatmeal, banana, or scrambled eggs for older child and small finger foods for toddler.
Walks children to daycare/preschool or drops them at a trusted cooperative playgroup three times a week.
Checks the day's calendar with her spouse and leaves notes on the fridge if there are special pickups or schedule changes.
workday: Builds client work around childcare windows: heavy design work from 9–12 and 2–4 when children nap or are at daycare.
Attends one remote client meeting midday and one quick creative-brief session in the late afternoon.
Takes a midday walk with a coffee to reset between client tasks.
Stops work by around 5–6 PM to handle family dinner logistics; answers urgent client messages in the evening only if necessary.
evening: Family dinner between 6:00–7:00 PM, often simple one-pot dishes.
Bedtime routine begins around 7:00–8:00 PM: bath, pajamas, teeth, bedtime story ritual with dim lighting and a particular lamp the kids love.
After kids are asleep, she and her spouse debrief the day, check the family's finances or calendar, and sometimes do 30–60 minutes of creative work.
Tries to be screen-free for at least 30 minutes before bed and reads design books or fiction.
Occasional early nights when deadlines are light, or late nights when a client rush requires it—these are exceptions rather than the norm.
weekend: Saturday morning farmers' market and relaxed brunch with other families.
Blocks of time for drawing or working on prints while spouse takes kids to a park playdate.
Afternoon playdates, library story hours, or visiting a museum's family program.
Sunday is reserved for a longer family walk, prep for the week (batch-cooking lunches, laying out clothes), and a simple homemade dessert.
One evening a month shared with friends for a casual dinner where the kids play together and adults rotate babysitting in shifts.

physical.general_state: Good overall health for a 34-year-old. Regular checkups with a primary care physician and pediatrician for children.
physical.pregnancy_history: Two pregnancies; uncomplicated vaginal delivery for the first child and a scheduled induction for the second. Managed mild iron deficiency during second pregnancy with supplements.
physical.allergies: Seasonal pollen allergies in spring; uses over-the-counter antihistamines as needed.
physical.fitness: Maintains activity through stroller walks, occasional yoga classes (2x/month), and weekend park play. No regular gym membership due to childcare priorities.
physical.sleep: Interrupted sleep patterns typical of parenting young children; strives for naps and early bedtimes when possible.
physical.substances: Non-smoker. Drinks wine socially, rarely more than 1–2 glasses. Avoids recreational drugs.
physical.vaccinations: Up to date on recommended adult vaccinations; children follow pediatric vaccination schedule.
physical.first_aid: Has basic first-aid and infant CPR training from a community class.

mental.baseline: Generally stable mental health with periods of heightened anxiety related to finances, childcare logistics, and work stability.
mental.therapy_and_support: Has worked with a therapist postpartum and uses occasional counseling check-ins; participates in a local parent support group every few weeks.
mental.stress_triggers: Client contract uncertainty, overlapping sick days at daycare, and major home maintenance issues.
mental.coping_strategies: Time-blocking tasks, leaning on spouse and neighborhood parent group, short breathing exercises, art as an emotional outlet, and planned social time with friends.

relationships.name: Mateo Rivera
relationships.occupation: Middle school Spanish teacher at a nearby public school
relationships.description: Supportive partner; they share parenting duties but sometimes struggle over last-minute childcare logistics. Mateo is steady, practical, and often the one to take late-night diaper duty. Their partnership balances creative and logical approaches—Harper handles freelance client-facing tasks while Mateo manages longer-term planning and school communications. They met at a community mural project.

relationships.name: Luna Santiago-Rivera
relationships.description: Curious, talkative preschooler who loves animals and books. Attends a small cooperative preschool three mornings a week. Likes to draw sun faces and insists on wearing a 'flower crown' during playtime.

relationships.name: Emilio Santiago-Rivera
relationships.description: Active toddler, beginning to string words together. Loves stacking cups and splashing in shallow water. Sleeps better on vacation, which complicates planning.
relationships.medical: Mild eczema in winter managed with moisturizer.

relationships.name: Ana and Roberto Santiago
relationships.description: Live within a 30–40 minute drive/up to an hour by transit. Very involved grandparents who help occasionally with childcare. Ana bakes often and brings prepared meals when Harper's workload spikes. Roberto helps with small home fixes.
A rotating group of 6–8 creative parents in the neighborhood: a photographer, a kindergarten teacher, a potter, and a freelance playwright—regularly trade babysitting favors and child hand-me-downs.

A small roster of recurring clients: two boutique food brands, one children's magazine editor who commissions seasonal illustrations, a production studio that hires Harper for art direction twice a year.
Several families in the building with young children; there's an informal WhatsApp group used for swap requests, outing planning, and safety alerts.
An older illustrator who gives Harper yearly feedback and occasionally collaborates on print projects; provides career advice and studio critiques.

other_facts: Born and raised in Queens, New York; first in her immediate family to attend art school.
Grew up bilingual: Spanish at home, English at school. Cultural food memories center on mole, arroz con pollo, and weekend pan dulce trips with Abuela.
Has a small tattoo of a paintbrush on the inside of her forearm commemorating her graduation year.
Keeps an Etsy shop with a curated selection of limited-run prints; it accounts for a modest supplemental income and occasional local craft-fair sales.
Student loan debt from art school remains a manageable but present monthly expense.
Monthly household rent is roughly in the mid-$2,000s for a two-bedroom in an accessible Brooklyn neighborhood; they prioritize location near parks and transit over larger living space.
Has a ritual of making a hand-drawn holiday card each year and mailing it to a close circle of friends and family.
Her first published illustration appeared in a small independent children's zine when she was 23 and felt like validation for pursuing art professionally.
Won a neighborhood small-business grant in the past to fund a kid-friendly mural project in a community garden; the mural still exists and children recognize her work there.
Once had a freelance client ghost on final payment; that experience shaped her current practice of using contracts and partial upfront payments.
Loves to collect vintage children's books and has a shelf of 1950s–80s picture books with quirky illustrations.
Is an occasional volunteer at the local library story hour and enjoys reading aloud with theatrical voices.
Keeps a labeled folder of favorite recipes, many passed down from her parents and adapted for quicker weekday cooking.
Has a small emergency savings account but is acutely aware it could be larger; focuses on building it steadily.
Has a simple 529 plan started for Luna with automatic monthly contributions; plans to add for Emilio next year.
Experienced postpartum anxiety after her second child and benefitted from therapy and a peer support group.
Her proudest professional moment: a small illustrated spread that ran in a regional parenting magazine and led to multiple commission inquiries.
Her biggest parenting worry: balancing screen exposure for kids with educational value and social time.
She and Mateo disagree sometimes about discipline thresholds; they resolved most issues by agreeing on consistent, small-step strategies.
Prefers to keep children's milestone photos private, sharing them only with select family and close friends, though she posts occasional cartoons of family life on social media.
Has a reliable pediatrician who is bilingual and recommended by several friends in the neighborhood.
She once organized a community swap of gently used baby gear, saving participating families hundreds of dollars and forming new friendships.
Owns a secondhand cargo bike in working condition but uses it more in summer for short grocery runs and playdates.
Has a small collection of vintage screenprinting posters from local shows and uses them in her apartment for inspiration.
Her favorite single-day getaway with kids so far was a small beach town two hours away by train where they rented an apartment with a kitchenette and spent slow mornings on the sand.
She keeps a small, laminated 'calm-down' card in her wallet with breathing steps learned in therapy to use during public meltdowns or panic spikes.
Harper's parents emigrated in their 20s; family gatherings include extended family from both maternal and paternal sides, often full of food and song.
She is active in local politics enough to attend an occasional community board meeting about playground renovations and votes consistently in local and national elections.
Dislikes 'toxic productivity' pitches online; she prefers realistic, sustainable routines that accept interruptions from family life.
Her favorite childhood memory is being taken to small murals and parades by her mother and learning to trace the lines of painted letters.
She keeps a simple 'work emergency binder' with contact numbers, contract templates, and step-by-step production notes in case she needs to hand off a job.
Has a mid-career ambition to produce a small children's book that addresses climate hope and practical kindness in a way young children can understand.
Harper values small acts of neighborhood kindness: returning a stroller that someone left in the lobby, bringing a neighbor soup when sick, and organizing a holiday food drive.
She once did a short residency at a local community art center where she led a workshop on making picture books with kids ages 3–7.
When stressed, she often bakes banana muffins as a soothing, sensory ritual and shares them with friends or neighbors.
Her favorite late-night creative gear is a small desk lamp, a notebook filled with thumbnails, and a playlist of quiet instrumental music.
She cares for a small houseplant collection in the apartment window: a snake plant, a pothos, and a baby aloe, all surviving despite inconsistent watering.
She keeps a pile of 'emergency kid entertainment' items: a portable felt board set, reusable sticker books, and a collapsible finger-paint mat for travel.
During a previous year, she and Mateo held a rotating babysit exchange with two neighbors, allowing each couple one evening out every three weeks.
She occasionally barters creative services in exchange for childcare with a trusted friend to keep costs down and strengthen community ties.
She is mildly competitive and proud about small things: getting a perfect espresso pull at the local cafe or matching colors perfectly in a print run.
Has a 'design day' once per quarter where she shuts client work and experiments with new techniques and subjects purely for joy.
Her social media handle reflects her art practice but she is careful to separate personal family images and does not monetize children’s likenesses.
